benchmark_details.name: Sequential-NIAH: A Needle-In-A-Haystack Benchmark for Extracting Sequential Needles from Long Contexts
benchmark_details.overview: The Sequential-NIAH benchmark is designed to evaluate the capability of large language models (LLMs) to extract sequential information items, known as needles, from long contexts. It includes three needle generation pipelines: synthetic-temporal, real-temporal, and real-logical orders, with context lengths ranging from 8K to 128K, comprising 14,000 samples.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To assess LLMs' ability to retrieve sequential information from long contexts in realistic scenarios.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: Model evaluations may be biased by the dataset's domain, and unoptimized API parameters could affect performance and fairness.

data.source: Synthetic and real data generated for LLM evaluation.
data.size: 14,000 samples (10,000 for training, 2,000 for development, 2,000 for testing)
data.annotation: The data is annotated using an evaluation model trained on synthetic data.

methodology.calculation: Metrics are calculated based on the comparison of LLM-generated answers with ground truth answers.
methodology.interpretation: Higher accuracy indicates better capability to extract and order retrieved information.
methodology.baseline_results: The best model achieved a maximum accuracy of 63.50% on the test set.
methodology.validation: The evaluation model achieved an accuracy of 99.49% in training on synthetic data.
